title: 103_hr2328
content: The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is cited as the short title for this Act. Congressional findings and purpose are outlined in the following section. The Congress finds that conserving natural and cultural resources through a Public Lands Corps can benefit young men and women by providing education and work opportunities, while also benefiting the economy and environment. Many public lands and Indian reservations require labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration work that federal agencies cannot carry out alone. Youth conservation corps have a good record of maintaining these facilities. The purpose of this Act is to perform cost-effective conservation, rehabilitation, restoration, and improvement work on public and Indian lands where existing employees cannot do so. It aims to expose young individuals to public service and enhance their understanding of natural and cultural resources. The Act aims to involve managing agencies in research and education on public lands, expose youth to public service and conservation careers, expand educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in conservation professions. The Act aims to involve managing agencies in research and education on public lands, expose youth to public service and conservation careers, expand educational opportunities, and stimulate interest in conservation professions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Corps" as the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" as lands owned or administered by the United States, "qualified youth or conservation corps" as programs offering work for individuals aged 16-25 in natural or cultural settings, and "Indian tribe" as any recognized tribe or band. The term "Indian tribe" refers to any recognized Indian tribe, band, nation, or group by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term "Indian" pertains to a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" encompass real property owned or held in trust by Indian tribes with restrictions on alienation. The term "Indian lands" includes real property owned by Indian tribes, held in trust by the United States, or subject to restrictions on alienation. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" involves preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrollees must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and can join without regard to civil service laws. Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps to carry out conservation projects on public or Indian lands. Preference is given to projects that provide long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic, are labor-intensive, can be started promptly, and offer educational opportunities. Projects under this Act must provide long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic, be labor-intensive, start promptly, and offer educational opportunities. All projects on public or Indian lands must comply with relevant laws and management plans. Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture can provide necessary services and establish conservation centers for programs under this section. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture are authorized to provide quarters, board, medical care, transportation, and other services for programs under this section. They can establish and use conservation centers for these programs, set health and safety standards, and make arrangements with the Secretary of Defense for logistical support. They may also enter into contracts with State and local government agencies and private organizations for the management of these centers. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. The Resource Assistant Program allows the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to place qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies for research or technical functions. Participants are recruited from colleges nationwide with a focus on diversity. The program aims to increase the workforce of these agencies and provide opportunities for college students and graduates. The Resource Assistant Program aims to augment the workforce of Federal land managing agencies by utilizing college students and recent graduates. Existing nonprofit organizations can implement the program, and private funding is required from participating organizations. Nonprofit organizations must contribute 25 percent of the total costs for interns in the Resource Assistant program they recruit. They must submit an annual report evaluating the program's scope, size, and quality, including the value of work contributed by the interns to the agency's mission. SEC. 6. Living allowances and terms of service for participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program are provided by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture. Living allowances cannot exceed those set for participants in the national service program. Participants agree to a specified term of service. SEC. 7. Educational benefits or awards are available for participants. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program are eligible for national service awards and forbearance on Stafford Loans. The benefits and awards eligibility criteria are determined by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture. Borrowers serving in these programs can request forbearance on their loans. Borrowers in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program can request loan forbearance while serving in the program and eligible for post-service educational benefits. SEC. 8. Nondisplacement requirements apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. Funding details. Cost sharing for projects on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps is authorized, with the government paying up to 75% of costs. Nonfederal sources can cover the remaining 25%. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Public Lands Corps can receive contributions from a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency. Funding for programs under this section is available under the National and Community Service Act. The Act authorizes cost sharing for projects on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps, with the government covering up to 75% of costs. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are eligible to receive funds under the National and Community Service Act for programs, without restrictions. Appropriations are authorized as necessary to carry out the Act.
